DIA_EPI.name: Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency
DIA_EPI.description: Pancreatic insufficiency occurs when the gland is damaged enough to stop functioning sufficiently. Normal absorption of nutrients in the small intestine is thus compromised resulting in nutritional deficiencies.

DIA_THD.name: Hashimoto's thyroiditis
DIA_THD.description: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease where the immune system gradually destroys the thyroid gland.

DIA_HPT.name: Hypothyroidism
DIA_HPT.description: Hypothyroidism is a disease where the thyroid gland functions inadequately and produces too little thyroid hormone.

DIA_HRT.name: Grave's disease
DIA_HRT.description: Grave's disease is an endocrine disease where the thyroid gland produces thyroid hormones in excess.

DIA_OES.name: Esophagitis
DIA_OES.description: Esophagitis is an inflammation of the oesophageal lining, often caused by acid reflux.

DIA_OEV.name: Esophageal varices
DIA_OEV.description: Esophageal varices are abnormally enlarged veins within the esophagus. They are usually caused by portal hypertension due to existing liver disease.

DIA_HBP.name: H. pylori infection
DIA_HBP.description: Helicobacter pylori is a bacteria present in the upper gastrointestinal tract. It is the main cause of peptic ulcers.

DIA_GAU.name: Peptic ulcer disease
DIA_GAU.description: A peptic ulcer is an open lesion in the lining of the stomach, duodenum or esophagus. It is most commonly caused by the bacterium h. pylori or prolonged, excessive use of NSAIDs

DIA_GAS.name: Gastritis
DIA_GAS.description: Gastritis is an inflammation or erosion of the stomach's lining. It is caused by; bad nutrition, excessive alcohol use, or excessive use of some medications. Treatment consists of protone pump inhibitors and discontinuation of alcohol or drugs that cause the symptoms.

DIA_DUO.name: Duodenitis
DIA_DUO.description: Doudenitis is an inflammation of the lining of the duodenum; the first part of the small intestine, which is 12 inches long and curved into the C-shape.

DIA_APP.name: Appendicitis
DIA_APP.description: Appendicitis refers to infection in the appendix, which becomes obstructed and swollen. A ruptured appendix can be fatal and thus appendicitis is one of the most common reasons for abdominal surgery.

DIA_CRH.name: Crohn's disease
DIA_CRH.description: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the entire intestine. The exact cause is unknown, however, it is evident that there are genetic, environmental and autoimmune components.

DIA_ULC.name: Ulcerative colitis
DIA_ULC.description: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that produces ulcers in the large intestine. The exact cause is unknown, however, it is evident that there are genetic, environmental and autoimmune components.

DIA_IBS.name: Irritable bowel syndrome
DIA_IBS.description: Irritable bowel syndrome is chronic gastrointestinal disorder demanding a long term treatment approach. It is not contagious. Diet modification and medicine can usually relieve symptoms.

DIA_FDR.name: Bacterial gastroenteritis
DIA_FDR.description: Bacterial gastroenteritis is common gastrointestinal disease, in most cases lasting a few days.

DIA_FOI.name: Fistula of the intestine
DIA_FOI.description: A fistula is an abnormal anatomical connection between two hollow spaces.

DIA_PER.name: Primary peritonitis
DIA_PER.description: Primary peritonitis is a bacterial infection of the peritoneum; a membrane covering the inner abdominal wall and organs within the abdominal cavity. Left untreated the condition is almost always fatal.

DIA_HEF.name: Hepatic fibrosis
DIA_HEF.description: Hepatic fibrosis represents an accumulation of scar tissue in the liver. The scar tissue can be the result of long term inflammation or another liver disease caused by viruses, bacterias, malnutrition or alcohol abuse etc. If left untreated it causes cirrhosis.

DIA_CIR.name: Cirrhosis
DIA_CIR.description: Cirrhosis describes a condition where the liver is malfunctioning due to long-term damage; normal liver tissue is replaced with scar tissue.

DIA_CLT.name: Gallstones
DIA_CLT.description: Gallstones, also called cholelithiasis, are concretions of  usually made from bilirubin, bile acids and calcium formed in the gall bladder. Gallstones usually do not cause symptoms, however, if they block the bile duct they can cause a variety of serious conditions.

DIA_CLS.name: Cholecystitis
DIA_CLS.description: Cholecystitis is inflammation and infection of the gallbladder, usually due to blockage of the cystic duct by a gallstone.

DIA_CLA.name: Cholangitis
DIA_CLA.description: Cholangitis is an infection of the bile duct usually caused by bacteria ascending from the duodenum. It occurs usually when the bile duct is already partially blocked by gallstones.

DIA_APT.name: Pancreatitis
DIA_APT.description: Pancreatitis refers to inflammation of the pancreas. It is usually caused by gallstone blockage or excessive alcohol abuse.

DIA_COE.name: Coeliac disease
DIA_COE.description: Coeliac disease is an autoimmune disorder where the immune system reacts to dietary gluten present in wheat, rye and barley. The reaction causes inflammation in the small intestines and thus malabsorption of nutrients.

DIA_ANS.name: Glomerulonephritis
DIA_ANS.description: Glomerulonephritis refers to inflammation of the filtering unit of the kidneys. It can be caused by an infection or autoimmunity.

DIA_TIN.name: Interstitial nephritis
DIA_TIN.description: Interstitial nephritis is an inflammation of the interstitial tissue of the kidneys. It can be caused by an infection or as an adverse reaction to medication.

DIA_PNS.name: Pyelonephritis
DIA_PNS.description: Pyelonephritis is inflammation of the kidney, usually due to ascending bacteria spreading up through the urinary tract.

DIA_ARF.name: Acute renal failure
DIA_ARF.description: Acute renal failure refers to an abrupt loss of kidney function, effectively seizing the ability to filter the blood and produce urine. The causes can be many, but are usually due to extensive tissue damage or decreased kidney blood flow.

DIA_CKD.name: Chronic kidney disease
DIA_CKD.description: Chronic kidney disease refers to a gradual loss of kidney function. The most common cause is untreated diabetes mellitus.

DIA_COK.name: Kidney stones
DIA_COK.description: Kidney stones, also known as urolithiasis, are usually concretions of calcium. Even though the stones usually pass on their own through the urinary tract, it is an extremely painful condition.

DIA_COU.name: Calculus of ureter
DIA_COU.description: Kidney stones, also known as urolithiasis, are usually concretions of calcium. Even though the stones usually pass on their own through the urinary tract, they can sometimes get stuck in the ureter, which is an extremely painful condition.

DIA_CIB.name: Calculus in bladder
DIA_CIB.description: Bladder stones can be formed in the bladder due to a mineralization of concentrated urine. There will only be symptoms if the flow of urine is compromised.

DIA_ACS.name: Urinary tract infection
DIA_ACS.description: UTF, or cystitis, is an infection of the bladder usually by E. coli; a type of bacteria commonly found in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. It is a condition a hundred times more common in women due to a shorter urinary tract.

DIA_INC.name: Interstitial cystitis
DIA_INC.description: Interstitial cystitis is also called painful bladder syndrome.

TRM_LIP.name: Liver laceration
TRM_LIP.description: Liver laceration occurs when an object pierces the tissue of the body and tears the liver.

TRM_LIB.name: Liver contusion
TRM_LIB.description: Liver contusion happens due to physical trauma to the upper abdomen.

TRM_SRB.name: Blunt spleen rupture
TRM_SRB.description: Blunt spleen rupture is caused by impact, injury or physical attack, but with no presence of an open wound.

TRM_SRP.name: Penetrated spleen rupture
TRM_SRP.description: Penetrated spleen rupture happens when an object pierces the skin of upper abdomen, causing an open wound and spleen damage.

TRM_SCB.name: Spleen contusion
TRM_SCB.description: Spleen contusion refers to bruising of the spleen after a direct impact to the upper abdomen.

TRM_PCB.name: Pancreas contusion
TRM_PCB.description: Pancreas contusion happens due to physical trauma to the upper abdomen.

TRM_PLB.name: Blunt pancreas laceration
TRM_PLB.description: Blunt pancreas laceration is caused by impact, injury or physical attack, but with no presence of an open wound.

TRM_PCP.name: Penetrated pancreas laceration
TRM_PCP.description: Penetrated pancreas laceration happens when an object pierces the skin of upper abdomen, causing an open wound and pancreas damage.

TRM_KLP.name: Renal laceration
TRM_KLP.description: Renal laceration occurs when an object pierces the tissue of the body and tears the kidney.

TRM_KCB.name: Renal contusion
TRM_KCB.description: Renal contusion refers to bruising of the kidney (latin: ren) after a direct impact to the upper lower back.

DIA_047.name: HUS
DIA_047.description: Hemolytic uremic syndrome refers to the condition when small blood vessels in kidneys become damaged and inflamed. In most cases an infection of Escherichia coli is responsible.

DIA_048.name: Campylobacteriosis
DIA_048.description: Campylobacteriosis refers to a common infection caused most commonly by Campylobacter jejuni. It is often a food-borne illness.

DIA_HEPA.name: Hepatitis A
DIA_HEPA.description: Hepatitis refers to a viral infection of the liver. Hepatitis A virus spreads through feces and usually occurs in areas with poor sanitation or hygiene.

DIA_HEPB.name: Hepatitis B
DIA_HEPB.description: Hepatitis refers to a viral infection of the liver. Hepatitis B virus spreads via blood, sexual contact or from mother to child.
